title.rendered: They warn about a virtual scam with the cards of “The Squid Game”

content.rendered:
Spain. The Spanish police are warning about a new type of scam that is implementing the popularity of the Netflix series “El Juego del Calamar”, number one on the platform for the Iberian country and 89 other countries in the world, to take advantage of its victims. and steal your money.

According to the authorities, the strategy consists of lead people to a web page that you have categorized as an “infectious site” and there steal your personal and bank details.

How do they do that? Implementing the invitation cards that are seen in the first chapters of the series. In South Korean production, each of the participants receives a cardboard card on which three figures are drawn, a circle, a square and a triangle, which symbolize the forms used to play the “squid game” and at the same time the hierarchies of the guards of the red monkey guarding the participants.

They warn about a virtual scam with the cards of “The game of the squid”.

In the series, behind the card there is a telephone number that the contestants call to find out the day and time they will be picked up and in which they express their willingness to participate in the game.

Fraudsters have imitated this card, placing a QR code on the back which leads to the aforementioned page, thus seeking to steal data, money and vital information from people who in real life follow the instructions of the squid.

That is why the National Police has launched an alert using their social networks in which they show the cards used by criminals to take advantage of the fervor of the fans and the idea that this may be a publicity stunt.

But it is not, that is why the authorities are reiterating to people that they do not enter unknown web pages and do not follow QR codes of those who are not sure of their origin.

“Be wary if you see a QR code in a public place. If we scan a code and we don’t know if it is trustworthy, it can take us to infectious sites and endanger our devices,” warns the Police.

With this new modality, the thieves seek to capitalize on the popular Netflix series that made the platform double its profits compared to last year thanks to the boom in views that the premiere of the South Korean production brought.
